ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I became much more comfortable with Japanese speaking and listening, and had the opportunity to learn a lot more about Japanese culture along the way.
Greater command of writing, listening, and speaking Japanese. Upper level grammar & vocabulary explored with native content in the form of movies, manga, literature, and articles.
A better understanding of Japanese, particularly kanji. There was also a lot that I learned about Japanese culture from the readings and from class.
I learned a lot in this course! The balance of grammar and kanji was great.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an excellent, well organized course. I have no complaints.
The main strength of JAPN 150 is Stever-sensei! Her passion and knowledge for the language was always infectious, and she constantly provided feedback on how to speak and write more naturally.

I think I would have learned more if the vocab/kanji tests were longer or included more material from previous units, but this would have increased the workload which I think was good. The course does an excellent job improving reading skills.

The course is really great. The weakness was my placement into this course (I was placed too high and was told I could not take a lower course, so I struggled quite a bit to keep up with the material).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I can't recommend Japanese at Yale enough!
Yes, definitely, if you want to continue studying Japanese at Yale or do a Light Fellowship.
I would recommend this course! Its definitely a step up from L4, though, so be prepared to put in the work.
